raw_text:
Microsoft gets the blogging bug
 
 Software giant Microsoft is taking the plunge into the world of blogging.
 
 It is launching a test service to allow people to publish blogs, or online journals, called MSN Spaces. Microsoft is trailing behind competitors like Google and AOL, which already offer services which make it easy for people to set up web journals. Blogs, short for web logs, have become a popular way for people to talk about their lives and express opinions online.
 
 MSN Spaces is free to anyone with a Hotmail or MSN Messenger account. People will be able to choose a layout for the page, upload images and share photo albums and music playlists. The service will be supported by banner ads. "This is a simple tool for people to express themselves," said MSN's Blake Irving. This is Microsoft's first foray into blogging, which has taken off as a web phenomenon in the past year. Competitors like Google already offer free services through its Blogger site, while AOL provides its members with journals. Accurate figures for the number of blogs in existence are hard to come by. According to blog analysis firm Technorati, the so-called blogosphere, has doubled every five and a half months for the last 18 months. It now estimates that the number of blogs in existence has exceeded 4.8 million, although some speculate that less than a quarter are regularly maintained.
llama3.2:1b: Microsoft launches MSN Spaces blogging service, allowing anyone with an email account to create and publish online journals called blogs.
The service is free, featuring customizable layouts, image uploads, photo albums, music playlists, and banner ads.
It will be supported by Microsoft's advertising efforts, marking the company's entry into the blogging world.
llama3.2:3b: Microsoft is launching MSN Spaces, a blogging service free to Hotmail or MSN Messenger users, allowing them to create online journals with layout options, image upload and sharing capabilities.
gemma2:2b: Microsoft is launching MSN Spaces, a free blogging service using their Hotmail or MSN Messenger accounts.
The service allows users to publish blogs, share photos and music, and includes banner ads.
This marks Microsoft's first foray into the growing world of blogging, which has seen significant growth in popularity recently.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Microsoft launches blogging service, called MSN Spaces, to allow users to publish their blog content online.
The website is free for anyone with an account from Hotmail or MSN Messenger but people can customize the layout of the page and upload images and photo albums and music playlists.
The service will also be supported by banner ads.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Microsoft launches an MSN Spaces service allowing users to publish blogs (web logs) using Hotmail or MSN Messenger accounts; it is free and supports banner ads; it follows competitors like Google and AOL in offering blogging services; Microsoft's first foray into blogging, coinciding with its popularity as a web phenomenon.
qwen2.5:3b: Microsoft launches MSN Spaces as a blogging service to compete with Google and AOL's existing offerings.
Free for Hotmail/MSN Messenger users, it allows customization and sharing features like photo albums and music playlists.
Microsoft views this as a simple platform for self-expression in an online trend that has seen rapid growth, with blog counts doubling every 5.5 months over the past year.
Despite facing challenges from established players, MSN Spaces represents Microsoft's entry into the blogging market.
opencoder:1.5b:
Microsoft's Blogging Bug

Software Giant Microsoft is Taking the Plunge into the World of Blogging.
Blogs, short for web logs, have become popular ways for people to talk about their lives and express opinions online.
MSN Spaces is free to anyone with a Hotmail or MSN Messenger account.
Users will be able to choose a layout for the page, upload images, share photo albums and music playlists.
It's easy for people to set up web journals, and "This is a simple tool for people to express themselves."
Microsoft's first foray into blogging has gone beyond just being a web phenomenon in the past year.
smollm:1.7b: Microsoft is launching a test service to allow people to publish blogs, or online journals, called MSN Spaces.
Microsoft is trailing behind competitors like Google and AOL, which already offer services which make it easy for people to set up web journals.
Blogs, short for web logs, have become a popular way for people to talk about their lives and express opinions online.
MSN Spaces is free to anyone with a Hotmail or MSN Messenger account.
People will be able to choose a layout for the page, upload images and share photo albums and music playlists.
The service will be supported by banner ads.
"This is a simple tool for people to express themselves," said Microsoft's Blake Irving.
This is Microsoft's first foray into blogging, which has taken off as a web phenomenon in the past year.
Competitors like Google already offer free services through its Blogger site, while AOL provides its members with journals.
Accurate figures for the number of blogs in existence are hard to come by.
According to blog analysis firm Technorati, the so-called blogosphere, has doubled every five and a half months for the last 18 months.
It now estimates that the number of blogs in existence has exceeded 4.8 million, although some speculate that less than a quarter are regularly maintained.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Microsoft is Launching MNs Spaces for Blogging with Free Service Available to Users with Hotmail or MSN Messenger.
Competitors like Google and AOL offer blogs, making it competitive in the space.
tinyllama:1.1b: Microsoft is launching a test service to allow people to publish blogs called MSN Space.
The service is free for users with an account on Hotmail or MSN Messanger, and features an easy layout for uploading images and sharing photo albums, as well as music playlists and photo galleries.
MSN's Blake Irving claims that this new blogging service is a simple tool to express oneself, although it has yet to figure out how many people there are actually using the service.
Competitors like Google and AOL also offer free services for blogging.
However, according to Technorati's figures, the number of blogs in existence exceeded 4.8 million as of May 2016.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Microsoft has been testing its own blogging platform, MSN Spaces.
The blogging service allows users to create and publish personal online journals called "Blogs" or "Web Journals".
MSN Spaces is designed as a free tool for users who have an active Hotmail or MSN Messenger account.
With the support of banner ads, Microsoft aims to reach out to a large audience by offering this convenient and accessible blogging platform.
phi:2.7b: Microsoft launches test service MSN Spaces, offering free blogging to users with Hotmail or MSN Messenger accounts, where they can choose layouts and share photo albums and music playlists through banner ads.
This is the company's first attempt at blogging, which has become increasingly popular in the past year.
Technorati estimates that there are over 4.8 million blogs currently online.
orca-mini:3b: Microsoft is launching a test service called MSN Spaces to allow people to publish blogs, which have become popular ways for people to talk about their lives and express opinions online.
The service is free to anyone with a Hotmail or MSN Messenger account and allows users to choose layouts, upload images, share photo albums and music playlists.
Supported by banner ads, this is Microsoft's first foray into blogging, which has become a web phenomenon in the past year.
Competitors like Google already offer free services through its Blogger site, while AOL provides its members with journals.
Technorati, a blog analysis firm, estimates that the number of blogs in existence exceeds 4.8 million, although some speculate that less than a quarter are regularly maintained.
hermes3:3b: Microsoft enters blogging market with MSN Spaces.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Microsoft enters the blogging arena with MSN Spaces, a testing service allowing people to publish online journals.
Launching initially as a free service for Hotmail and MSN Messenger users, it allows bloggers to customize their page, upload images and share music playlists.
Following competitors like Google and AOL who already offer similar services, Microsoft enters the blogging market which has grown significantly in popularity over the past 18 months.
While accurate figures of blog existence are hard to determine, the blogosphere is estimated by Technorati to have exceeded 4.8 million blogs, with a doubling trend every five and a half months.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Microsoft is entering the blogging market with MSN Spaces, a free service for Hotmail and MSN Messenger users to create and customize blogs, share photos, and music playlists.
The service, supported by ads, follows similar offerings from competitors like Google and AOL.
Blogging has rapidly grown in popularity, with the number of blogs doubling every five and a half months, reaching over 4.8 million, though many are not regularly maintained.
stablelm2:1.6b: Microsoft launches MSN Spaces to allow users to publish blogs (or online journals) for free with customizable layouts and sharing options.
This is Microsoft's first involvement in blogging, which has become popular as a web phenomenon over the past year.
Competitors like Google and AOL offer similar services through their own platforms, while AOL provides members with journals.
As of August 2004, Technorati estimated that the blogosphere had surpassed 4.8 million blogs, though some argue fewer than one-quarter are maintained regularly.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Microsoft, following competitors like Google and AOL, introduces MSN Spaces, a free blog-publishing service for users with Hotmail or MSN Messenger accounts.
Users can customize layouts, add images, photo albums, and music playlists.
The service will be supported by banner ads.
Microsoft's Blake Irving described it as a tool for self-expression.

Despite being late to the market, MSN Spaces aligns with the rapid growth of blogging, which Technorati estimates has surpassed 4.8 million active sites, though less than a quarter are actively maintained, having doubled every 5.5 months over the past 18 months.
